positive.review: This idle game is really fun! It would be even better if some of the QoL features werent locked behind certain levels and were available right from the start, like the auto-sell or equipment filtering system. I've already completed 100% of the Steam achievements at the moment but I still feel like Ive barely touched the end-game content. Like many other adventurer management idle games, my biggest gripe is the end-game. Since the enemy debuffs basically force you to use specific units and equipments, limiting your viable options. Still, thats a common issue in the genre, and overall the game is still very enjoyable.

[b]This is more of a feedback and demands for some tips and mechanics. Thanks in advance to devs. :3[/b]

Well, i simply need an open and clear tutorial on how to use Equipment Filtering. I don't know how to use it, i don't know how it works and if it works at all. 

Please, at least for the endgame, put a skill changing npc or smth for classes. Let me change or customise the skills of my characters as i want at the end game. 

And why the rates of rare items finding don't improve as we progress in the levels? Why they are all the same in lvl1 dungeon and in lvl99? Doesn't make sense. Make set items more important for example. Don't push us to go min/maxing stats. The one way to beat the game, like 2 paladins with cast speeds and 1 necro with amplify arcane dmg or smth. Balance the game more and cherish other characters and all the items more. 

Well, that's all.

[b]Edit:[/b]
Maybe a different category in inventory for Charms? It's difficulty to manage or even see them among other items. Or just make a better ''sort'' feature. And maybe some levels for charm farming? They are game changers but they do not have any level for them.

Loot of Baal is a distinctive idle action RPG developed and published by Gleamer Studio that merges the satisfying loop of loot hunting with the laid-back mechanics of background progression. It takes the addictive qualities of classic hack-and-slash RPGs—loot drops, stat optimization, and class variety—and reinterprets them for a player who doesn’t always have time to grind actively. Instead of forcing constant micromanagement, the game allows players to recruit heroes, equip them, and send them into battle automatically while the action unfolds on its own. This structure creates a sense of continuous advancement even when the player isn’t fully engaged, turning Loot of Baal into a game that rewards both attention and passivity, balancing strategy and convenience in an appealing way.

The foundation of the game lies in its five core classes—Mage, Paladin, Ranger, Berserker, and Necromancer—each of which offers a distinct playstyle and combat rhythm. Every hero can be upgraded, geared, and customized through a wide variety of systems that include crafting, rune socketing, upgrading, and synthesizing. The loot system is exceptionally ambitious for an idle game, featuring over a thousand unique items and hundreds of rare and immortal artifacts with different affixes that alter stats and behavior. What makes the looting process engaging is the surprising depth of itemization: a player may find themselves balancing resistances, attack modifiers, and critical multipliers, just like in full-fledged ARPGs. Even though the gameplay unfolds largely on its own, the management of equipment, build creation, and hireling synergy provide constant decisions that make the experience intellectually engaging rather than purely automatic.

A major strength of Loot of Baal is how it integrates idle mechanics without diluting the satisfaction of tangible progress. Watching your heroes return from expeditions with rare gear feels rewarding, and the moment-to-moment loop of checking upgrades and refining builds offers the same dopamine rush as actively playing a dungeon crawler. The crafting system deepens this further, letting players dismantle old gear to build new ones or infuse them with runes that alter elemental affinities and stats. This system is supported by an intuitive though somewhat cluttered interface, where inventory management between multiple heroes can occasionally feel cumbersome. Yet the amount of depth packed into a seemingly minimalist design is impressive, and the gothic aesthetic—shadowy halls, demonic foes, and glowing relics—evokes a nostalgic feeling reminiscent of old-school dark fantasy ARPGs.

Performance-wise, the game is lightweight and designed to coexist with multitasking. It runs efficiently in the background and uses minimal system resources, which fits its purpose perfectly for players who like to have a game running while doing other work. The visual presentation focuses more on clarity and tone than spectacle, using stylized models and sharp contrast to maintain visual identity. There is also generous language support, covering English, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and several European languages, which expands its accessibility and player reach. The sound design, while subtle, reinforces the otherworldly setting, with quiet ambient cues and rhythmic battle effects that accompany the idle progression.

Despite its impressive scope, Loot of Baal is not without flaws. Some players report interface inconsistencies and difficulty navigating inventory systems, particularly when managing several heroes simultaneously. The pacing, too, can suffer as the game moves into higher levels; the early game is fast and gratifying, while the late game becomes an extended grind where experience gain slows dramatically and new rewards feel scarce. This shift from discovery to routine is a common issue in idle RPGs, but here it’s especially noticeable because of the strong early-game momentum. Still, for players who appreciate long-term incremental progression rather than instant gratification, the gradual climb can be part of the appeal.

The developer deserves credit for a fair monetization model. Unlike many idle games that rely on aggressive microtransactions or gated progress, Loot of Baal keeps its paid content optional and cosmetic. The support packs and boosters do not create a pay-to-win dynamic, which helps maintain a sense of integrity in the player’s achievements. This makes the game suitable for both free players who enjoy the slow burn and those who wish to support development financially without gaining an unfair advantage.

Overall, Loot of Baal successfully carves a niche for itself in the crowded idle gaming landscape by combining the strategic depth of traditional RPGs with the ease and persistence of idle play. It offers satisfying build experimentation, generous loot variety, and an appealing visual identity, all while functioning seamlessly in the background. While it could benefit from a more polished interface and richer late-game content, it remains a compelling experience for those who enjoy the art of optimization and the thrill of treasure hunting without the need for constant hands-on action. For players who like their gaming experiences to coexist with their daily tasks, this title from Gleamer Studio offers a darkly enchanting balance of activity and autonomy.

Loot of Baal is a distinctive idle action RPG developed and published by Gleamer Studio that merges the satisfying loop of loot hunting with the laid-back mechanics of background progression. It takes the addictive qualities of classic hack-and-slash RPGs—loot drops, stat optimization, and class variety—and reinterprets them for a player who doesn’t always have time to grind actively. Instead of forcing constant micromanagement, the game allows players to recruit heroes, equip them, and send them into battle automatically while the action unfolds on its own. This structure creates a sense of continuous advancement even when the player isn’t fully engaged, turning Loot of Baal into a game that rewards both attention and passivity, balancing strategy and convenience in an appealing way.

The foundation of the game lies in its five core classes—Mage, Paladin, Ranger, Berserker, and Necromancer—each of which offers a distinct playstyle and combat rhythm. Every hero can be upgraded, geared, and customized through a wide variety of systems that include crafting, rune socketing, upgrading, and synthesizing. The loot system is exceptionally ambitious for an idle game, featuring over a thousand unique items and hundreds of rare and immortal artifacts with different affixes that alter stats and behavior. What makes the looting process engaging is the surprising depth of itemization: a player may find themselves balancing resistances, attack modifiers, and critical multipliers, just like in full-fledged ARPGs. Even though the gameplay unfolds largely on its own, the management of equipment, build creation, and hireling synergy provide constant decisions that make the experience intellectually engaging rather than purely automatic.

A major strength of Loot of Baal is how it integrates idle mechanics without diluting the satisfaction of tangible progress. Watching your heroes return from expeditions with rare gear feels rewarding, and the moment-to-moment loop of checking upgrades and refining builds offers the same dopamine rush as actively playing a dungeon crawler. The crafting system deepens this further, letting players dismantle old gear to build new ones or infuse them with runes that alter elemental affinities and stats. This system is supported by an intuitive though somewhat cluttered interface, where inventory management between multiple heroes can occasionally feel cumbersome. Yet the amount of depth packed into a seemingly minimalist design is impressive, and the gothic aesthetic—shadowy halls, demonic foes, and glowing relics—evokes a nostalgic feeling reminiscent of old-school dark fantasy ARPGs.

Performance-wise, the game is lightweight and designed to coexist with multitasking. It runs efficiently in the background and uses minimal system resources, which fits its purpose perfectly for players who like to have a game running while doing other work. The visual presentation focuses more on clarity and tone than spectacle, using stylized models and sharp contrast to maintain visual identity. There is also generous language support, covering English, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and several European languages, which expands its accessibility and player reach. The sound design, while subtle, reinforces the otherworldly setting, with quiet ambient cues and rhythmic battle effects that accompany the idle progression.

Despite its impressive scope, Loot of Baal is not without flaws. Some players report interface inconsistencies and difficulty navigating inventory systems, particularly when managing several heroes simultaneously. The pacing, too, can suffer as the game moves into higher levels; the early game is fast and gratifying, while the late game becomes an extended grind where experience gain slows dramatically and new rewards feel scarce. This shift from discovery to routine is a common issue in idle RPGs, but here it’s especially noticeable because of the strong early-game momentum. Still, for players who appreciate long-term incremental progression rather than instant gratification, the gradual climb can be part of the appeal.

The developer deserves credit for a fair monetization model. Unlike many idle games that rely on aggressive microtransactions or gated progress, Loot of Baal keeps its paid content optional and cosmetic. The support packs and boosters do not create a pay-to-win dynamic, which helps maintain a sense of integrity in the player’s achievements. This makes the game suitable for both free players who enjoy the slow burn and those who wish to support development financially without gaining an unfair advantage.

Overall, Loot of Baal successfully carves a niche for itself in the crowded idle gaming landscape by combining the strategic depth of traditional RPGs with the ease and persistence of idle play. It offers satisfying build experimentation, generous loot variety, and an appealing visual identity, all while functioning seamlessly in the background. While it could benefit from a more polished interface and richer late-game content, it remains a compelling experience for those who enjoy the art of optimization and the thrill of treasure hunting without the need for constant hands-on action. For players who like their gaming experiences to coexist with their daily tasks, this title from Gleamer Studio offers a darkly enchanting balance of activity and autonomy.

interestingly, around level 30, I tested a build for a melee skill on Assasin. Legendaries seem completely useless. You're only left with time grind, which makes the game hollow. But they do have an update planned for this month that sounds like it will make things better, so I'll revisit.

Like I'm progressing just due to time and will probably launch the game just to launch it here and there, but there's just too many times where I have no idea if any of these numbers on my gear mean anything or if it can amount to something since we don't really have any control over besides their tier and 2 skills.

Plus, it's just time consuming to try experimenting or testing things since it takes a lot to even invest in just 3 squad members repeatedly AND most gear seem the same unless I'm missing something big

I hate this game, it could be so good if someone competent made it. UI is horrible, localisation is a joke because some text are overflowing and unreadable, directionless. I cant tell how good it gets after 20 hours, but the first hour or so is really bad, yet you can see it has potential which annoys me.
is windowed mode for the game that hard?
Need more time in the oven.

interestingly, around level 30, I tested a build for a melee skill on Assasin. I wanted to compare to compare the damage/dps of several different weapons on the dummy, but I found that the overall damage and dps was the same, no matter which weapon I used - and the same when I used no weapon at all. (the damage of the weapons varied quite a lot - but it made no difference. dodgy to say the least, made me stop playing because I realize that the equipped weapon makes no difference basically.)

Nah. Things are badly explained, takes forever to try out a build and it's not clear how stats affect things. So you can't really theory craft to make the best team possible. Legendaries seem completely useless. You're only left with time grind, which makes the game hollow. But they do have an update planned for this month that sounds like it will make things better, so I'll revisit.

This was a game I saw around when it first came out, but missed the chance to buy it because it was DMCA'd off steam. Cut to now, and it seems it still has the UI issues that it had even way back then. The game is neat and all, but my god the UI and the way the game is presented ruins it completely for me. Hopefully they overhaul at least the fullscreen setting at some point to make it decent.

Fun when it works.  Half the time it wants to stay offscreen.  Opening inventory and managing inventory between mercenaries is terrible because the inventory tab is so small or is half offscreen.   Could be a fun idler if they could fix menu management.

Idler with huge grind element and with no offline progress.
Why?

P. S.: i'm sure later it will be more interesting, but for now...

After I uninstalled the game nothing weird has happened again.
